issues.description: The problem statement and UML describe/expect a fully implemented class named Meal (with constructor Meal(String, String[]) and getters). The template repository, however, does not contain an implementation of Meal (Meal.java is empty) and instead provides a class named Order with the Meal-like API. The solution repository implements Meal as expected. This type/class-name mismatch (Order vs Meal) and the missing Meal implementation in the template will confuse students: they will either have to recreate/rename classes to match the specification or change references in the problem/solution, and the provided starter code will not compile/run as intended for the exercise described.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template match the problem statement: remove or rename the extraneous Order class and provide a fully implemented Meal class in the template with the constructor Meal(String, String[]) and getters for name and ingredients (matching the UML). Update any template/Main references if needed so that starter code compiles and clearly matches the exercise description.

issues.description: The problem statement and the solution implementation use a class named 'Meal' to represent a meal with its ingredients (and the UML and requirements refer to 'Meal'), but the provided template repository contains a class named 'Order' with the same structure (name, ingredients) while Meal.java in the template is empty. This creates an unnecessary naming mismatch: students reading the problem expect to find/extend a Meal class in the starter code, but the template provides an identically purposed class under the different identifier 'Order'. This mismatch can confuse students about which class to use/modify and forces them to map the conceptual entity 'Meal' <-> implementation 'Order' (extra cognitive load) or to rename files/classes manually.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the template to the problem by providing a Meal class in the starter code (or renaming Order.java to Meal.java and the class to 'Meal') so the identifier matches the problem statement and solution. Update any references in Main or other template files to use 'Meal'. Alternatively, if 'Order' was intended, update the problem statement and solution to consistently use 'Order' instead of 'Meal'. Prefer renaming the template's Order -> Meal to preserve the problem text and solution naming.
